text:
RANJAY GULATI: Phil
Jackson, the former coach

of the Chicago Bulls
and the Lakers,

said that obsession with
winning is a loser's game.

My first interest in
sports was because I
was an athlete myself.
So I love sports.

And I always wanted to
know, what do coaches do?

And I remember talking to
Pete Carroll, the coach

of the Seattle Seahawks,
and he asked me,

he said, so, Ranjay,
what do you do?

So I'm an
organizational theorist.

I said, I study how to unlock
organizational potential.

So I asked him, I
said, what do you do?

He said, I unlock
human potential.

I was intrigued by that
answer and it really

made me realize that's what
leadership is all about.

It's all about unlocking human
potential, both individually
and as a team, as a collective.

You know, my first thought when
I met a sports coach, which

was really the idea
that they would

say it's all about
winning, because that's

what you do when
you're playing a sport.

I was really kind of surprised
to learn that many of them,

not all of them,
many of them say,

no, it's not about winning, it's
about the process of playing.

And are you playing to your
best, to your best potential?

Any sport, there's going
to be winning and losing.

And as one coach, John
Wooden said, you know,

where there are peaks,
there4 are valleys.
What can I learn from winning?
What can I learn from losing?

In researching, there
are some common themes
that cut across great coaches.

And I came up with five T's,
talent, training, teamwork,
tenacity, and transformation.

I'm going to walk you
through what great coaches do

by leveraging the
key levers that

allow them to unlock that great
human potential individually
and collectively.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
